attributes.action: Declare that the 42 Days Detention Debate is based on a fallacy
attributes.action_prefix: We the undersigned petition the Prime Minister to
attributes.background:
"Davis", though correct, sustains a Good Friday Agreement folly.  Decommissioning applies only to weapons IRA  called  "Stunts", Bomb and Bullet. 

Debate, and appalling ideas to burn Magna Carta, is based on  fallacies terrorism is only about bomb and bullet and that Police and MI5, backed by inadequate civil contingency, can combat terror.  

"Stage 3" of the IRA plan is not in the GFA and is sabotage (by security cleared sleepers in the unions the sort of people first in the queue for an ID card)

The most potentially serious interdicted IRA attack was July 1996, pre-emptive warnings came from whistleblower civil contingency concerns not MI5 or Police alone. IRA set out to to black out mains power.

If known unreliability of emergency backup generators ensues during the provoked nuclear plant shutdowns (see Dounreay) nuclear hazards or  Multiple Chernobyl result ... 

the crux:

(a) Direct attacks on mains fit the debate (MI5) model of terrorism.

(b) The consequences of such an attack are not in the too narrow debate.  These are the woeful state of civil contingency.

The debate must be both about interdiction and survival.

Tony Blair appeared to finally recognise that in April 2005

reasons: Wording that needs to be amended, or is impossible to understand
